Title: Fat Chance: Probability from the Ground Up
Short Description:
Summary:
Fat Chance is a course designed for beginners in probability who want an accessible review of core concepts before taking a college-level statistics course. The course focuses on developing a mathematical mode of thought rather than rote memorization of terms and formulas. It explores the quantitative reasoning behind probability and the cumulative nature of mathematics by tracing probability and statistics back to principles of counting. The course is divided into modules that cover basic counting skills, simple probability problems, adapting techniques to solve more complex probability problems, and introducing statistics through expected value, variance, and the normal distribution. Topics covered include Basic Counting, Advanced Counting, Basic Probability, Expected Value, Conditional Probability, Bernoulli Trials, and The Normal Distribution.
Skills: Statistics, Basic Math, Probability, Guided Practice, Probability And Statistics, Normal Distribution
Cost: FREE-Add a Verified Certificate for Rs. 4091.5

Title: Chasing your Dream: How to End Procrastination and Get a Job You Love
Short Description:
Course Summary: 
This course is designed for individuals who feel stuck in their careers and are looking to make a change. It draws from academic teachings in motivation and positive psychology from top universities such as Harvard and Moscow State University, as well as cultural studies from Tibet. Throughout the course, participants will learn how to resist procrastination, engage in self-determination, and tackle obstacles that may be hindering their personal development. While the course does not offer a quick fix solution, it provides tools for solving key problems and gaining the basic skills of self-development. 

Week 1: Introduction to the series of courses "Chasing your Dream." 
Week 2: Focus on decision-making and taking on responsibility with the 'Take on Responsibility' Tool. 
Week 3: Learn how to concentrate on advantages and effectively apply them with the 'Green Pen' Tool. 
Week 4: Overcome the fear of mistakes and move through discomfort with the 'Cult of Mistakes' Tool. 
Week 5: Reflect on what has been understood and learned throughout the course, and plan for the future.

It includes interviews with individuals who have used surrogacy and sperm donation, as well as medical professionals and bioethicists. Title: Shakespeare's Hamlet: The Ghost
Short Description: This course is a study of William Shakespeare's Hamlet, focusing on the character of the Ghost of the dead King of Denmark. The course, led by Harvard professor Stephen Greenblatt, delves into the historical contexts of the play and the Ghost's significance in Shakespearean times. Learners will explore narrative sources, religious beliefs about the afterlife, and the Ghost's impact on the original audience. The course examines themes of death, mourning, remembrance, and the power of theatre in the play. Through video lectures, readings from Hamlet and other works, and discussions with experts, participants will gain critical tools to interpret the play's meanings. The course is suitable for both first-time readers of Hamlet and those revisiting the classic tragedy. It is divided into four parts: analyzing the Ghost's introduction in Acts 1-2, exploring religious controversies in Acts 3-4, considering the play's themes of revenge and remembrance, and studying the earliest printed texts of Hamlet in a broader historical context.

It covers the etiology of heart attacks, type 2 diabetes, stroke, and other cardiovascular diseases, as well as biological modifiable risk factors like blood pressure, blood cholesterol, and obesity. Participants will gain insight into underlying pathophysiological mechanisms such as insulin resistance and (epi)genetic factors. Additionally, the course explores the interaction between nutrients, diets, and cardiometabolic diseases, with a focus on prevention through lifestyle and dietary modifications. It is especially beneficial for professionals in nutrition, health, and related fields. The course is structured into modules covering topics such as cardiometabolic disease risk, the role of diet in prevention, pathophysiology, molecular aspects, and nutritional strategies to reduce cardiometabolic diseases.
Skills: Health Policies, Public Health, Insulin Resistance, Type 2 Diabetes, Biology, Cardiovascular Disease, Cancer, Disease Etiology, Diabetes Mellitus, Blood Pressure

Title: Embedded Systems - Shape The World: Microcontroller Input/Output
Organization: The University of Texas at Austin
Short Description:
Summary:
The course is part one of a two part sequence that teaches students how to design and build electronic gadgets as embedded systems. Students will learn to build solutions to real-world problems using embedded systems, starting with simple interfacing of switches and LEDs and progressing to complex concepts such as microcontroller-based pacemakers, digital locks, and traffic light controllers. The course covers general principles and practical tips for circuit building and programming in C language. Students will develop debugging skills using oscilloscopes, logic analyzers, and software instrumentation. The course includes eight labs, with highlights being designing software algorithms for a demand pacemaker, interfacing switches and LEDs, and creating a finite state machine for a traffic light controller. Students will need to purchase a Texas Instruments TM4C123 microcontroller kit and electronic components to complete the course. Labs will be completed first in simulation and then on real boards, with projects ranging from running projects with switch inputs and LED outputs to creating traffic light finite state machines.
Skills: ARM Architecture, Embedded Systems, Algorithms, Finite State Machine, C (Programming Language), Problem Solving, Debugging, Purchasing, Oscilloscope, Network Switches, Artificial Cardiac Pacemakers, Logic Analyzer

Title: Project Management of Engineering Projects: Preparing for Success
Short Description:
This business and management course focuses on project management skills and the early project phases, with examples from technical projects in various sectors. By the end of the course, participants will create a project execution plan either individually or in teams. 

Week 1 covers the importance of project management and how project success is achieved. Week 2 emphasizes the importance of teamwork in project success and challenges faced by project managers in developing coherent teams. 

Week 3 delves into opportunity framing, including identifying stakeholders, scoping projects, and setting up risk registers. Week 4 discusses project assurance plans and contracting strategies. 

Week 5 explores selecting the appropriate contracting strategy and introduces the concept of relational attitudes. Week 6 focuses on scheduling and cost estimation skills. 

Week 7 brings everything together in the project execution plan to be delivered by the end of the week.

Title: Molecular Biology - Part 2: Transcription and Transposition
Short Description:
Summary:
The Molecular Biology: Transcription and Transposition course delves into the transcription of DNA to RNA, exploring transposable elements that make up 50% of the human genome. The course covers how these "jumping genes" work and their link to certain diseases. It also discusses modern molecular genetics, from classic experimental events to cutting-edge assays. The course focuses on experimental design, data analysis skills, and the limits of current knowledge on transcription machinery and mechanisms of transposition. Topics covered include bacterial and eukaryotic transcription machinery and promoters, regulation, and CRISPR technology. Join this challenging course to enhance your understanding of molecular biology.

Title: Embedded Systems - Shape The World: Multi-Threaded Interfacing
Organization: The University of Texas at Austin
Short Description:
Summary:
This course is part two of a two-part sequence where students will learn how electronic gadgets are designed, developed, and built as embedded systems. The course focuses on using interrupts to design real-time systems such as audio players, data acquisition systems, control systems, and interactive games. Students will learn how to build solutions to real-world problems using embedded systems, starting from simple interfacing of switches and LEDs to more complex concepts like display drivers, digital to analog conversion, motor control, and communication. The course includes hands-on laboratory assignments that are first performed in simulation and then on a real microcontroller. By the end of the course, students will be able to build their own arcade-style game from scratch. The course requires the purchase of a Texas Instruments TM4C123 microcontroller kit and a few electronic components. The labs in the course cover topics such as UART, interrupts, digital to analog conversion, analog to digital conversion, game design, and wireless communication. Students can pick and choose labs to achieve certification, with the most rewarding labs being the hand-held video game, sound generation, and smart object creation using Wifi communication. This course provides a comprehensive understanding of embedded systems design and programming in the C language.
Skills: Digital Audio Player, Communications, ARM Architecture, Embedded Systems, Data Acquisition, Smart Objects, Circuit Switches, C (Programming Language), Problem Solving, Instrumentation, Network Switches, Debugging, Electronic Components, Oscilloscope, Purchasing, Control Systems, Motor Control, Logic Analyzer

This course focuses on the production of hydrocarbons from unconventional reservoirs using horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing. The course follows the textbook Unconventional Reservoir Geomechanics by Mark Zoback and Arjun Kohli. Title: Know HBV And HCV
Short Description:
Summary:
Viral hepatitis is a significant public health issue worldwide, causing deaths exceeding those from HIV/AIDS. The majority of deaths result from liver cancer or cirrhosis related to undiagnosed or untreated chronic hepatitis B or C infections. The course "KNOW HBV/HCV" aims to educate healthcare workers on prevention and control of hepatitis through online modules based on reputable sources such as professional societies, WHO, and CDC. Upon completion, participants will understand the burden of chronic hepatitis, transmission routes, prevention strategies, diagnosis, and management. Developed by the Asian Liver Center at Stanford University, the course consists of 3 modules, a post-test, and a survey covering topics such as liver cancer burden, viral hepatitis types, prevention of blood-borne infections, and needlestick injury management.
Skills: Vaccination Administration, Disease Control, Infection, Primary Care, Hepatology

Title: Designing and Leading Learning Systems
Short Description:
Summary of Course Description:
- The course focuses on the importance of collaboration between students, teachers, and educational leaders to achieve ambitious teaching and learning goals.
- Learners will explore four leading logics of educational innovation, including strategies to improve educational practice and outcomes on a large scale.
- Each logic has been successful in various educational settings but also has potential pitfalls.
- Learners will analyze exemplary cases of large-scale educational innovation in the US and abroad to understand the potential and pitfalls of these logics.
- By understanding these logics, learners will be able to strategically design and manage local innovation and identify external programs for partnership.
- The course is part of the Leading Educational Innovation and Improvement MicroMasters Program offered by MichiganX.
- Part 1 focuses on reviewing leading logics of educational innovation, while Part 2 involves analyzing cases of large-scale, practice-focused educational innovation, including Success for All, Reading Recovery, and England's National College for Teaching and School Leadership.

Title: Proteins: Biology's Workforce
Short Description:
Summary:
This biology course focuses on proteins, which are essential for almost all living processes. Students will learn how proteins are the cellular manifestation of genetic information and play a vital role in metabolic reactions, DNA replication, response to stimuli, movement, and more. The course covers protein structure, function, purification, and characterization through lectures, articles, case studies, and molecular models. Topics include the components of proteins, their 3-dimensional shapes, bond structures, and the diverse roles they play in living organisms. Various methods for protein purification and characterization will be explored to understand how proteins are involved in driving living processes.
Skills: Biology, Protein Structures, Metabolism
Cost: FREE-Add a Verified Certificate for Rs. 14111.5

Title: Introducción a los ritmos y relojes biológicos
Short Description:
Summary:
The online course covers the topic of biological clock and biological rhythms, and their impact on health and daily life. It explores how the body responds to different stages of the day, the study of circadian rhythms, and the influence of external factors on our biological clock. The course highlights the importance of understanding our biological clock and how it affects various activities such as sleep, appetite, and work. It also explains how the internal clock regulates physiological functions and the significance of synchronizing it with external signals like light. The course consists of modules focusing on the history of chronobiology, the effects of light on the biological clock, the regulation of physiology by the biological clock, and the role of the biological clock in health and disease, including issues like jet lag.
Skills: Circadian Rhythm, Biological Process, Physiology, Metabolism, Biology
Instructor: Mario Eduardo Guido-Eduardo Garbarino Pico-Ágata Carpentieri-María Ana Contin
Cost: FREE-Add a Verified Certificate for Rs. 4175.0

Title: Introducción a las ondas gravitacionales
Short Description:
Summary:
This course provides an introduction to gravitational waves, taught by expert Gabriela González from the LIGO project. Topics covered include the combination of data from multiple telescopes to create images of objects in space, the study of black holes using light telescopes, an overview of gravity theories by Newton and Einstein, the detection and properties of gravitational waves, and the astrophysics of gravitational waves. The course is divided into modules focusing on Einstein's general theory of relativity, the sources of gravitational waves, the detection methods, and the astrophysical implications of studying gravitational waves. Students will learn about the significance of gravitational waves and how they provide insights into various astrophysical systems.

Title: Computational Neuroscience: Neuronal Dynamics of Cognition
Short Description:
Summary:
This course explores the mathematical and computational models used in theoretical neuroscience to understand decision-making, memory recall, perception, and neuronal dynamics. Topics covered include associative memory, attractor networks, neuronal populations, perception, decision making, and synaptic plasticity. The course is based on the textbook "Neuronal Dynamics" and includes online lectures, exercises, quizzes, and a final exam over a 6-week duration. Participants will gain an understanding of how thousands of interacting neurons work together without a central control unit.

Short Description:

The course focuses on the challenges of urbanization and population growth, with a projected increase of 2.5 billion people in urban areas by 2050. It aims to explore how cities can become sustainable to support this growth, with a focus on adapting to new technologies, energy systems, and modes of transportation.
